Description: An L-shaped lift or slide key, used to open a simple tumbler lock. Top portion of key, missing its handle. Rectangular. Three pronged key end. Extremely corroded; one of three parts.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Redpath Museum, Montreal. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of similar keys were found at Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum AN1888.189; Boston 86.355, 86.354, 86.353; British Museum EA 1885, 1101.82; Fitzwilliam Museum GR.72.1887; Montreal 2522a-c; Petrie Museum UC59869d). Roman parallels from the Fayum and Egypt in the Petrie Museum (UC71705, UC63742, UC63769-77, 83-5, 90; Petrie 1917, 60, pl.76, W200). An L- shaped lift or slide key, used to open a simple tumbler lock, used in the Roman period and found across the Roman Empire, including Britain (where they were used since the late Iron age, Manning 1985, 89-93). Manning, W. H. 1985. Catalogue of the Romano-British iron tools, fittings and weapons in the British Museum. London : BMP. Petrie, W.M.F. 1917, Tools and Weapons. London. University college, London, and 2,000 outlines from other sources. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TD.05) (Phase 3)
